title: Stable-token Registry
description: We need a way to monitor and verify stable tokens prior to using them to purchase goods and services.

f6_assessments.q0: This could be a nice idea. However it requires a lot more detail to be a viable proposal. I have significant experience in financial markets and verifying the backing of a stable contract is not as simple as looking at the assets. If it is fully backed then, yes. But what about fractional backing (how all banks work)? What if it is set up like the SigmaUSD token on Ergo, or Djed, where USD value is backed by at risk assets? This requires stress testing and correlation analysis. If a national authority is providing insurance, then where does the blockchain come into it?
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer has does not have financial markets experience and has stated that they will use the requested funds of $10,000 to get a developer to do it. However what will the developer build? The proposer should bring in people with experience and create a plan to execute. Only then can the plan be costed with an idea on whether it will be able to be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
Not metrics for measuring success have been provided.  Is the proposer going to create a new stable coin and audit it? Are they going to audit a current stable coin? how will they get that stable coin to let them audit? Just look at the issues with Tether. The US government can't even force a proper audit. 
The proposers should provide a detailed plan and what they are going to do, then the some metrics for success. This could be create a new coin and publish verifiable data on backing. OR provide that data for a new coin,, etc.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a short but precise proposal highlighting the need to have a platform to verify the backing of Tokens before being used  and proposed a solution that utilises an Oracle to achieve that.

I agree.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal provide verifiable link of experience but it was clearly stated that an engineer will be hired to execute the solution and a timeline of 3 months was provided .

 I can neither agree nor disagree considering the proposal lacks a detailed implementation plan and cost implication breakdown.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal did not provide sufficient information to audit the progress and success of the proposal solution.
A cost breakdown, Timelines with milestones will make this proposal go a long way in future funding rounds .
I disagree.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal problem statement is not very clear to me,
There are four primary stablecoin types, identifiable by their underlying collateral structure: fiat-backed, crypto-backed, commodity-backed, and algorithmic , I am not quite sure which of them the proposal is addressing.
I believe the proposal can be refine and be more specific which of the stable coin and how it will impact ADA holders. Secondly I think the proposal is trying to interwoven a Crypto Solution with Traditional institution as a means for verification, which defeat the purpose of smart contract and transparency of decentralisation without any third party involvement,I am rating 2
f6_assessments.q1: If the proposer successfully finished the Plutus Pioneer program as claim, I think the experience is good enough to build this proposal but the plans are lacking , The definition of success for 3 , 6 and 12 months is not detailed enough , there is no roadmap , No start date. Based on the information provided , I strongly disagree this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: There is no KPI/Metrics provided to audit the progress and the success of the Proposal

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposer has one more submittion in which he intends to create a mechanism for making tokens of Certificate of Deposit (CD) which is a negotiable instrument. This will create trustable crypto coins with 100% backing of USD.
This proposal is to create a smart contract that can verify that the tokens in fact have backup CD supporting them using third-party oracles.
This proposal forms an important part of the trust chain. The idea to have a stable coin that can be created by anyone, but provable backed by Fiat CD is a very nice system that has the power of a decentralized stable coin ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer need to hire a developer for writing the smart contract. The idea and the implementation details are clear therefore it is likely that the proposer will be able to get the project implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The deliverable is a metadata server and oracle system to monitor and verify the correspondence between a stable token and the actual CD backing the token. The code has to be open source for adoption to happen since one metadata server and an oracle are not sufficient to create the trust that is required while issuing stable coins. There output of the project is realistic and measurable therefore it can be audited and the successes easily quantifiable.

f6_assessments.q0: The solution of the problem described in the proposal suggest the creation of a metadata server, however reading the solution and detail plan it is not clear when and how transaction metadata would be used in the project. One can assume that the server authenticity will be proved by Cardano transaction, but it not completely clear to understand if the proposal fit in this challenge. Note that the challenge is for projects or POC where metadata solve the problem traceability, authentication, and auditability for example. I recommend to better develop the idea behind metadata usage.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer explains with details the problem that it's trying to solve and gave a solution to it. What it does not provide is a detailed plan of actions needed to achieve that goal. For that reason, we cannot fully agree that the problem is totally feasible. I recommend elaborating the plan in actionable items and deliverables.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal does not include a detail plan of actions neither presents deliverables or something that can be use to track the progress of the project. However, there's an expected release timeline and a budget allocation for just one developer. The lack of more detailed information will make hard to audit the project but not impossible.

solution: I propose the creation of a metadata server and oracle system to monitor and verify the correspondence between an asset and its backing.
